accessPolicy.confirmDelete:
You're about to delete this access policy.
Are you sure?
accessPolicy.invitationsAlert: You can invite participants directly. That does not require any other access policies. Invited users will see the meeting when they log in.
accessPolicy.noAccessPolicies: The meeting has no access policies
accessPolicy.noAccessPoliciesAlert: The meeting is visible to everyone, but there is no way to join it. Create and activate and access policy if you want users to be able to join without an invitation.
accessPolicy.listedMeetingHelp: Is it okay to show this meeting to users on the organisation start page? They will only be able to access basic details if they aren't participants.

automatic.title: Automatic
automatic.description: Allows for public access to the meeting. With this policy active, anyone will be able to join your meeting, and will immediately receive selected roles. Existing participants will not be affected.
automatic.joinDescription: This meeting is open to everyone in the organisation. Om you join the meeting, other participants will be able to see you, and you'll get the following roles:

activeUsers.confirmDismiss:
Choosing to retain inactive status in a meeting may affect voting rights in polls.
Are you sure?
activeUsers.description: Users will be asked if they're active in meeting.
activeUsers.dialogDescription: The meeting officials wants to know if you're currently active in this meeting.
activeUsers.dialogInformation: The information can be used to determine voting permissions, and other participants will be able to se who's active. You can change this later using the control in the bottom of the meeting menu.
activeUsers.groupActiveDescription: Number of active group members. Participants may be counted in multiple groups.
activeUsers.listDescription: An active user is any participant in the meeting that's marked themselves as active.
activeUsers.listEmpty: This meeting doesn't have any active users yet.
activeUsers.purgedCount: No users were marked as inactive | One user was marked as inactive | {count} users were marked as inactive
activeUsers.purgeInactiveHelp: You can clear active status for participants in this meeting that hasn't shown any activity for selected amount of hours.
activeUsers.title: Active users

electoralRegister.activeDescription: Electoral registers used in ongoing polls
electoralRegister.confirmMethodChange: Are you sure you want to change method for electoral registers to {name}?
electoralRegister.created: A new Electoral Register was created
electoralRegister.createHelp: Pick users from potential voters to create a new electoral register.
electoralRegister.dialectChangeMethodDisallowed: You can't change this setting in this meeting, because it has a dialect setting that requires a specific electoral register method.
electoralRegister.failed: Failed creating new Electoral Register. Try later, or contact support.

electoralRegister.selectMethod:
You haven't selected a method for setting electoral registers in this meeting.
Electoral registers are used to determine which users can vote in polls. Setting a method is required for you to be able to start a meeting.
electoralRegister.upToDate: No need to update Electoral Register
electoralRegister.weightedVoterCount: No voters | One voter ({total} votes) | {count} voters ({total} votes)

auto_always.description: This method will always create a new electoral register when potential voters change. Should only be used in demo meetings.
auto_always.title: Demo meeting: Always update electoral register

auto_before_poll.description: This method automatically creates electoral registers as needed, from potential voters, when a poll is started.
auto_before_poll.title: Automatic on poll

manual.description: When using this method, the meeting moderator creates electoral registers manually. Allows for weighted votes.
manual.title: Manual

presence_check.description: This method creates a new electoral register upon closing a presence check. Voting rights will be given to present users with the role potential voter.
presence_check.title: Presence check

home.noVisibleMeetings: You currently don't have any visible meetings in this organisation.

home.noMatchingMeetings: Found no meetings that match your filter.

invites.addUserInvitesWarning: Use with precaution! Participants should normaly be added using invitations.

invites.helpTextBody: An invitation means that a user with that email address will be able to join your meeting. Men VoteIT will not send invitation emails - you have to do that yourself. Use the copy button below to copy all email addresses in the list.
invites.noInvitesHelp: Noone has been invited to this meeting yet.

If you continue, {title} will be cleared from all annotated invites.

annotate.helpText: This form is for adding additional functions to your invites. Copy and paste from a spreadsheet like in the template below. To be able to annotate invites, there must be existing invites to this meeting with the user data that you're annotating.

mixed.helpText: In order to invite using mixed user data, you'll need to copy and paste from a spreadsheet document. The first row must be headers that defines the type of user data in that column, according to the table below.
mixed.label: Paste user data

Do you want to join as moderator?

language.disclaimer: Your choice of language affects VoteIT itself - the contents of buttons, menus, etc. It will not affect user submitted content in your meetings.

groups.help: Members in a group can post proposals in that groups name, wherever the user has permission to add proposals. This is useful for adding proposals from a committee or other group, that should not be considered personal proposals.
groups.importHelp: Import multiple groups using group name and id (tab-separated). Copy and paste from a spreadsheet document.
groups.importWithVotesHelp: Import multiple groups using group name, id and vote count (tab-separated). Copy and paste from a spreadsheet document.
groups.removeUserConfirm:
You're about to remove {user} from this group.
Are you sure?

poll.voteAddedInfo:
Your vote has been accepted.
You can change your vote at any time until the poll is closed.

majorityWinner.title: Majority winner
majorityWinner.description: A majority (more than 50 %) must prefer this, otherwise it shouldn't be able to win.

majorityLoser.title: Majority loser
majorityLoser.description: If a majority of voters do not want this, it shouldn't be able to win.

mutualMajority.title: Mutual majority
mutualMajority.description: If there's a subset of proposals which a majority of the voters prefer to every other proposal, then the winner must come from the subset. Example: Alice (apple with 30% vote share) and Granny Smith (apple with 30% vote share) goes against Navelina (orange with 40%). All Alice/GS fans prefer the other apple over the orange, so one of the apples should win.

condorcetWinner.title: Condorcet winner
condorcetWinner.description: The winner must beat every other candidate in a pairwise comparison.

condorcetLoser.title: Condorcet loser
condorcetLoser.description: The loser must loose against every other candidate in a pairwise comparison.

cloneProof.title: Clone proof
cloneProof.description: The winner must not change due to strategic nomination, for instance that a similar candidate runs.

proportional.title: Proportional
proportional.description: The result should reflect the user base as a whole, for instance: If 20 percent of the electorate support a particular political party as their favorite, then roughly 20 percent of seats will be won by that party. Applies to multiple winner methods.

dutt.majorityProposal: A majority of the voters selected the proposal
dutt.minorityProposal: The proposal was not selected by a majority
dutt.maxHelpText: Select one less proposal for a valid vote | Select {count} fewer proposals for a valid vote
dutt.minHelpText: Select one more proposal for a valid vote | Select {count} more proposals for a valid vote

IRV.numRounds: Instant-Runoff Voting, one round | Instant-Runoff Voting, {count} rounds
IRV.repeatedRoundResult: IRV is not a method deisgned to elect multiple winenrs. Each round in a repeated IRV is a simple IRV, with the winners from previous rounds omited. Because each simple IRV has several rounds, there is no simple answer to how many votes a proposal got, other than that it would have at some point got a mojority of the votes. How many rounds that took is irrelevant.

majority.tiedResult: The poll got a tied result.

description.combined_simple: Each proposal will be voted individually, with the options to approve, deny or abstain.
description.dutt: This poll methos shows which proposals has the highest approval, but can't appoint majority winners or losers. If a proposal was selected by a majority of voters, it's likely, but not certain, that the proposal is supported by a majority. It could also be the result of tactical voting or mandatory amount of selections. The method can be used for opinion surveys and guiding polls, but should be avoided for making real decisions.
description.irv: Ranked poll with a single winner. Voters rank proposals by order of preference. Proposals with least amount of votes will be excluded and votes transfered until one proposal has more than 50 % of the votes.
description.majority: Voters choose between two proposals. The one with the most votes wins.
description.repeated_irv: Simple IRV is repeated until all winners are elected, or until no proposal can get a majority. Repeated IRV can easily be manipulated by syncronizing votes, and should be avoided.
description.repeated_schulze: A regular Schulze poll is repeated until all candidates have a ranking. The result is non-proportional, and each stage produces the Condorcet winner within the remaining candidates. Voters rank proposals with stars.
description.scottish_stv: Ranked poll with multiple winners. Voters rank proposals by order of preference. Surplus or discarded votes are transferred to reduce wasted votes.
description.schulze: Rank proposals with stars - more is better. The proposal that is prefered in pairwise comparison to every other proposal wins.

help.combined_simple: Vote approve or deny for each proposal.
help.irv: Select the proposals you want to vote for in order of preference.
help.scottish_stv: Select the proposals you want to vote for in order of preference.
help.repeated_irv: Select the proposals you want to vote for in order of preference.
help.schulze: Rate proposals with stars - more is better. To rate two or more proposals equal, set the same amount of stars. You don't have to rate every proposal.
help.repeated_schulze: Rate proposals with stars - more is better. To rate two or more proposals equal, set the same amount of stars. You don't have to rate every proposal.

schulze.numTiedWinners: A clear winner was established. | One ring to rule them all, and in the darkness bind them. | There was a tie between { count } proposals. The winner was randomly selected among those.

help.intro: Order list by clicking an icon or name in the table header below. The icons represent roles that decide what a user can do.
help.discusser: Allowed to add discussion posts if discussion is allowed, and the meeting hasn't closed.
help.moderator: May do most things within a meeting, including add other moderators.
help.participant: Can view the meeting and other participants.
help.potential_voter: Can become a voter if certain conditions are met. This depends on the method for creating an electoral register.
help.proposer: Allowed to add proposals if proposals are allowed and the meeting hasn't closed.
help.speaker: Speakers may enter open speaker lists, even if user doesn't have a required role.
help.voter: Exists as a voter within the latest electoral register. However, older polls may use older registers.
